posts.cooked: It is still a little early, but the Messaging Layer Security IETF proposal is slowly making progress toward approval. Signal should at minimum consider adopting parts of the standard to increase efficiency of larger group chats.

posts.cooked: Consider that Signal will always try to keep metadata collection to a minimum here.

@AlertSubject
This may be, but this is what they’ve had on the website since they created the WG. I posted this now because the drafts are in the last stage of approval and have been submitted for publication (so essentially final). I assume they won’t update the website until publication.

@Whatnoww
Understood, MLS is just a framework. Services can implement the standard in a wide variety of ways (from non-private to Signal-esque private)

posts.cooked:
meh, not to repeat myself:

How realistic is interoperability between Signal and other platforms? (Digital Markets Act)

There is MLS (The Messaging Layer Security, see IETF’s https://www.ietf.org/id/draft-ietf-mls-architecture-07.html) and the hope that this will ensure interoperability “easily” (pdf, p.8; BSI: Moderne Messenger – heute verschlüsselt, morgen interoperabel? , sorry in german only) , but I do not want to know what the supporters actually really want to achieve with this. On the other hand, why should FB&co have anything against getting even more (mata)data, from other services?

just some quotes from the recent ietf-blog (IETF | Messaging Layer Security: Secure and Usable End-to-End Encryption):

MLS builds on the best lessons of the current generation of security protocols. Like the widely used Double Ratchet protocol,

aha, double ratchet

… and the IETF MIMI working group expects to use MLS as the end-to-end encryption layer in their solution for interoperable messaging.

aha, interoperable messaging no, no, no (see How realistic is interoperability between Signal and other platforms? (Digital Markets Act))!

How realistic is interoperability between Signal and other platforms? (Digital Markets Act)

There is a reason why I never used WA for example.

posts.cooked:
@anon88132

Not sure what your point of view is. Signal can run their own MLS layer on their own infrastructure and not have to open it up. I’m mainly interested in the increased efficiencies for group messaging.
Is there much inefficiency left with Signal’s current groups? Never tried having a group with 1000 people so I can’t really tell.

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
Seems MLS is officially a standard now. From this read and from my understanding it seems to pretty much just be the Signal Protocol, right?

blog.mozilla.org

Messaging Layer Security is now an internet standard | The Mozilla Blog

Today, the Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF) is releasing the standard for Messaging Layer Security (MLS) protocol, a novel standard of communication

link_counts.title: Messaging Layer Security is now an internet standard

posts.cooked:
Didn’t have time to take a closer look (and haven’t seen anyone that I know/trust write about it), but standardizing something in 2023 without quantum-proofness in mind is …

I believe there were some attempts to make key distribution/sharing in groups more efficient?

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked: The deepest read I’ve done is this article, but it seems the standardisation here is of the general approach to encryption, so stuff like double-ratchet, perfect forward secrecy, group keys etc, and not stuff like “use RSA instead of ChaCha”. And as I understand it, the latter is what matters for post-quantum encryption, since the encryption algorithm itself is the weak link in the post-quantum world, not the way it is used.

Post-quantum security is easily done in MLS, @rassilon1963 is correct. MLS is a protocol built on lower-level primitives. If you want post-quantum security, you need to choose post-quantum secure primitives. And switching primitives is allowed and specifically designed for in MLS.

Here is a great overview (that specifically mentions post-quantum security) on RFC 9420 (Messaging Layer Security) by a contributor to the standard and developer of one of its first implementations (OpenMLS):

Phoenix R&D – 18 Jul 23

RFC 9420 aka Messaging Layer Security (MLS) - An Overview

Messaging Layer Security has been published. MLS is the first standardized, fully specified, freely accessible end-to-end encryption protocol.

Talya (she/her):

it seems to pretty much just be the Signal Protocol, right?

It provides many, if not all, of the same security guarantees of the Signal Protocol (PFS, PCS, etc) and is heavily inspired by the Signal Protocol, but improves in specific areas:

  • efficient private group messaging
    • Signal Protocol is a one-to-one protocol and to extend it to group messaging scenarios is ultimately an open problem (as exemplified by the many different ways that implementations have chosen: WhatsApp, Signal itself, Wire, Matrix’ Megolm). MLS is meant to standardize this extension to group scenarios.
    • MLS accomplishes this using the middle ground (in efficiency) of tree data structures for disseminating messages instead of the horribly inefficient 1-1 or very efficient, but less private, server fanout, while maintaining a security level of the one-to-one method
  • designed with federation as a goal (I know Signal isn’t publicly federated, but federation on internal networks is still potentially beneficial)
  • it’s an actual specification instead of the previous standard which was essentially libsignal’s source code (obviously doesn’t affect Signal too much)
